definition:
[**Definition**]{} Suppose $X,Y,Z$ are sets, and we have maps
$$\begin{aligned}
 f\colon Y&\to& Z, \\
 \Phi\colon X&\to& Y.\end{aligned}$$ Then the [**pullback**]{} of $f$
under $\Phi$ is the mapping $$\begin{aligned}
\Phi^\ast f\colon  X &\to& Z, \\
             x&\mapsto& (f\circ\Phi)(x).\end{aligned}$$

Let us denote by $M(X,Y)$ the set of all mappings $f\colon X\to Y$. We
then see that $\Phi^\ast$ is a mapping $M(Y,Z)\to M(X,Z)$. In other
words, $\Phi^\ast$ pulls back the set where $f$ is defined on from $Y$
to $X$. This is illustrated in the below diagram. $$\xymatrix{
 X \ar[r]^\Phi\ar[dr]_{\Phi^\ast f} & Y \ar[d]_{f} \\
  &  Z 
 }$$

### Properties

1.  For any set $X$,
    $(\operatorname{id}_X)^\ast = \operatorname{id}_{M(X,X)}$.

2.  Suppose we have maps $$\begin{aligned}
     \Phi\colon X&\to& Y, \\
     \Psi\colon Y&\to& Z\end{aligned}$$ between sets $X,Y,Z$. Then
    $$(\Psi\circ \Phi)^\ast = \Phi^\ast \circ \Psi^\ast.$$

3.  If $\Phi\colon X\to Y$ is a bijection, then $\Phi^\ast$ is a
    bijection and
    $$\big(\Phi^\ast\big)^{-1} = \big(\Phi^{-1}\big)^\ast.$$

4.  Suppose $X,Y$ are sets with $X\subset Y$. Then we have the inclusion
    map $\iota:X\hookrightarrow Y$, and for any $f\colon Y\to Z$, we
    have $$\iota^\ast f = f|_X,$$ where $f|_X$ is the of $f$ to $X$.
